MENTAL ILLNESS HITS THE MONEY TRAIL 

  (The Week in Review) 
(NOTE TO INTERNATIONAL CLIENTS: For use by special arrangement
only. Asian and European points: Call Karl Horwitz in Paris for
details and prices, phone: 47 42 17 11; fax: 47-42-80-44). Latin

310-996-0075; fax: 310-996-0089). 
(lb) 
 By JOE SHARKEY   
 c.1999 N.Y. Times News Service   

   Shouldn't people with mental illnesses, which can destroy lives
and families, be entitled to the same amount of insurance coverage
as those with physical illnesses? On the face of it, that sounds
like a fairly simple question.

   But as in all things having to do with health care, and
especially the often vaguely defined area of mental illness, the
issue can be maddeningly complicated.

   Tipper Gore, the wife of the vice president, will open a White
House conference on Monday to draft new health-care policies that
would require employers and insurers to provide coverage for
outpatient and inpatient mental health comparable to that for other
kinds of medical care _ ``parity for all,'' in the words of Mrs.
Gore.

   Along with similar proposals pending in Congress, the White
House initiative would face head-on what Mrs. Gore, who has a
master's degree in psychology, calls the destructive myth that
those seeking greater mental health coverage are ``out to rip off
the system.''

   At stake is a significant slice of the total U.S. health-care
budget. About $80 billion _ nearly 10 percent of total annual
health-care spending _ now goes into mental-health treatment,
according to the Center for Mental Health Services, a federal
research agency.

   About a third of that amount, mostly from Medicaid, Medicare and
other government sources, pays for clinical treatment of the
severely mentally ill, whose illnesses often render them poor and
unemployed and who often ``end up in the public system,'' according
to Mary Rappaport, a spokeswoman for the National Alliance for the
Mentally Ill, an advocacy group for the severely mentally ill.

   In any year, according to the group, about 5 million Americans
suffer from severe and persistent mental disorders, including
schizophrenia, bipolar disorders and major depression.

   Few seriously question the need for clinical treatment for those
with the worst mental illnesses, about 250,000 of whom are
homeless. So the debate over the potential cost of providing
comparable insurance coverage for mental and physical illnesses is
focused on those whose treatment consumes the remaining two-thirds
of the $80 billion total, most of which is paid by
employer-provided health insurance.

   This segment includes the ``worried well,'' as they are called
by those who question the employment of psychiatric therapy to
address many less severe emotional distresses and addiction
problems. For the past 25 years, most of the increases in
mental-health spending have gone to this group of patients, who are
the easiest and most profitable to treat.

   Proposed federal laws to establish comparable insurance coverage
for mental illness seek to give priority to the severely ill. But
some employers and policy analysts worry that once mandates for
expanded mental-health coverage are in place, costs could rise
sharply above the modest levels projected by the drafters of the
parity bills. The concern is that the legislation would provide
profit incentives to tailor diagnoses and to recruit new pools of
patients.

   Advocates of comparable insurance coverage cite studies showing
that the additional cost would be minimal, while providing a major
public-health benefit. The National Institute of Mental Health
predicts that mandating parity through managed-care plans would add
less than 1 percent to the total annual national health-care bill.

   But such studies could be flawed by ``very low assumptions on
induced demand,'' said Paul Fronstin, a senior researcher at the
Employee Benefit Research Institute, whose clients include
employers, labor unions and pension plans. ``Induced demand''
refers to marketing by the mental-health industry, usually among
patients with health insurance who can be successfully treated for
a wide array of mental disorders defined in the American
Psychiatric Association's Diagnostic and Statistical Manual.

   For employers and others worried about potential cost increases
in mental-health therapy, induced demand raises a red flag. In the
late 1980s, when expanded psychiatric and substance-abuse therapy
was heavily promoted and advertised among the general population,
annual costs for such treatments rose 20 percent to 30 percent
faster than costs in other areas of health care, employers found.

   Fraud also became a problem. In the early 1990s, for-profit
psychiatric hospitals and addiction centers paid over $500 million
in federal fines to settle charges of profiteering and diagnostic
fraud in recruiting patients with generous mental-health insurance.
Many health-maintenance organizations responded by tightening
benefits for inpatient hospitalization and other mental-health
treatment.

   For their part, advocates for comparable insurance coverage cite
evidence that they say shows that more money is needed for
additional mental-health treatment:

   _ In any year 30 million Americans suffer from clinical mental
disorders, but only about 20 percent currently seek treatment,
according to studies cited by the National Institute of Mental
Health.

   _ According to the American Society of Addiction Medicine, 11.3
percent of Americans will at some point require psychiatric
treatment for various addictions. In an April report, the group
called for more spending on addiction therapy.

   _ The National Institute of Mental Health recently launched a
national television and radio advertising campaign to encourage
more people to seek treatment for anxiety disorders, which the
agency describes as ``frightening mental illnesses'' affecting 19
million Americans.

   _ The National Alliance for the Mentally Ill cites studies
asserting that of the nation's 63 million youths under 18, about
7.5 million have diagnosable mental disorders _ but only about a
fifth now receive treatment.

   _ Post-traumatic stress disorder, which is prompted by memories
of traumatic events, is now widely diagnosed among victims and
witnesses of crimes, natural disasters and even marital problems.
The National Institute of Mental Health estimates that 4 percent of
the population suffers from it. But that number could grow. The
Justice Department recently stated that some people who are
swindled by telemarketing fraud and other white-collar crimes
develop post-traumatic stress disorder and require psychiatric
intervention.
